Yes, I still think your criticism is unwarranted.  
 
If org.w3c.dom.Document is calling the class loader itself, then problems
are to be expected when a different class loader is used.  Is that what it's
doing?  If I had the source I'd grep through it to see.
 
As Fergus noted, if you don't use JUnit's custom class loader, you have to
restart the test application after each recompile.  This causes a
significant slowdown in the edit-compile-test cycle.  Since the vast
majority of applications don't have to play explicit games with the class
loader, using the custom class loader for testing is a reasonable default.
The default used to be to use the system class loader, but that was changed
in version 3.3 and noted in the README file.  You're probably right that it
should be noted in the FAQ, since it does seem to come up frequently.
Actually, looking at the FAQ, I notice the junit.util.excluded.properties
noted there.  Perhaps this is another solution to the problem; you could run
a test or check the source code.
 
My points are that Erich and Kent have done us all a big favor by releasing
this code.  This code is still evolving; it's not surprising that the user
documentation lags behind the capabilities, especially since the authors
derive no remuneration for it.  However, the question about class loading
problems has been answered as often as it's been asked, and the answers can
be easily found both on sourceforge (
http://sourceforge.net/forum/message.php?msg_id=97007
<http://sourceforge.net/forum/message.php?msg_id=97007> ) and here (I
searched the archives for "loader constraints").  Searching the yahoogroups
archive, I found the message http://groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/419
<http://groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/419>  that verifies the
excluded.properties solution works.
 
So, it seems to me that you're whinging about losing time for which your
client is paying, and instead of thinking you should have determined the
problem quicker or thinking that solving such problems is part of
"delivering bullet-proof software," you're thinking that the authors of a
free test package (that saves you time) have failed you.  I'm sorry to have
to put it so bluntly, but you didn't get the hint in my previous message.
(BTW, if you check the JUnit zip file, you'll find test cases that indicate
the authors DID test the program.)  As I see it, you're still looking a gift
horse in the mouth and you still haven't answered the question, "how would
you have done it better?"
 
 - George

-----Original Message-----
From: Herrick, Chuck [mailto:chuck.herrick@...]
Sent: Tuesday, March 27, 2001 9:44 AM
To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
Subject: RE: [junit] cannot run testing with UI TestRunner?



Did you not see this? I noticed it was missing from your reply: 
-- 
I even tried rebuilding my app from a full set of source files (including 
dom source). 

The problem with the -noloading is that one can't rerun individual test 
cases after a rebuild :-( 

Fergus 
-- 
The classloader issue comes up not just with the org.w3c object. I tripped
across the -noloading botch myself, and wasted a good couple of hours trying
to diagnose my problems with it.

This kind of thing provides great material to use to trip up folks during
technical interviews, but is hardly conducive to the deliverance of
bullet-proof software when your client is paying you by the hour.

Finally, I'd point out that someone shows up in this Yahoo.group having
tripped over this JUnit classloader with a frequency of about 1 per week.
Given that, do you really think my criticism is unwarranted?

	-----Original Message----- 
From:   Dinwiddie, George [SMTP:George.Dinwiddie@...] 
Sent:   Tuesday, March 27, 2001 8:30 AM 
To:     'junit@yahoogroups.com' 
Subject:        RE: [junit] cannot run testing with UI TestRunner? 

	Chuck, 
  
I think your criticism is unwarranted.  First of all, I find JUnit to be a
wonderful help and I'm very glad to have it.  Second, the JUnit classloader
DOES work.  I don't know what's going on within org.w3c.dom.Document, but in
general, when the -noloading switch solves the problem it indicates that
some part of the software is using a different class loader and that results
in an object mismatch.  The response to this is to disable JUnit's reloading
class loader and use the default one (which will not reload changed classes)
that the software under test is expecting.  Is this a bad design decision?
Do you have a better solution to this problem?

	  
 - George 

	-----Original Message-----
From: Herrick, Chuck [ mailto:chuck.herrick@...
<mailto:chuck.herrick@...> ]
Sent: Tuesday, March 27, 2001 8:37 AM
To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
Subject: RE: [junit] cannot run testing with UI TestRunner?



	Take a look at the security machinations that Java demands the
classloader undergo on behalf of the virtual machine. 

	I would say that if JUnit can't complete some very fundamental piece
of its business because the authors made bad design decisions regarding the
classloader, you'd need to get someone to go back and refactor JUnit.

	Perhaps someone should have tested JUnit with some test software
before rolling it out.
